pageData.text: This investigation is an overview of mammalian anatomy. By dissecting a preserved rabbit specimen, you will explore the complexity of the various organ systems, gain experience in dissection procedures, and apply the fundamental terminology of anatomical discourse.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: External Anatomy - 30 minutes
Activity 2: The Muscular System - 60 minutes
Activity 3: The Digestive System - 45 minutes
Activity 4: The Respiratory System - 30 minutes
Activity 5: The Circulatory System - 60 minutes
Activity 6: The Urogenital System - 30 minutes
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: External Anatomy - 30 minutes
Activity 2: The Muscular System - 60 minutes
Activity 3: The Digestive System - 45 minutes
Activity 4: The Respiratory System - 30 minutes
Activity 5: The Circulatory System - 60 minutes
Activity 6: The Urogenital System - 30 minutes

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Apply basic anatomical descriptive terminology.
Use essential tools and techniques for performing a dissection.
Identify the major structures of mammalian organs and organ systems, and describe their primary functions.

pageData.text: When you think of model organisms used in biological research, organisms such as E.coli, fruit flies, and mice readily come to mind. But rabbits have their place in research as well. Rabbits are not only exemplary specimens for studying the structures of the class Mammalia, but they are also versatile model organisms for studying and treating human diseases. Although they are more difficult to maintain than rodents like mice and rats, rabbits offer researchers an animal model of intermediate size between small rodents and larger, but much costlier, models like primates. Rabbits also have longer lifespans than rodents, and studies have shown that rabbits have immune system genes that are more like those of humans1.One of the first uses of rabbits in disease research was in 1881 when Louis Pasteur used them to create his rabies vaccine. Today, rabbits as model organisms allow researchers to study the underlying mechanisms, and develop treatments and vaccines for, a wide variety of human diseases, such as syphilis, tuberculosis and HIV-AIDS1.
1Esteves, P.J., Abrantes, J., Baldauf, HM. et al. The wide utility of rabbits as models of human diseases. Exp Mol Med 50, 1–10 (2018). https://doi.org/10.1038/s12276-018-0094-1

pageData.desc: A rabbit sitting in grass.
pageData.altText: A rabbit sitting in grass.

pageData.text: The mammalian <button class='glossary-text'>body</button> is made up of organ systems, each with a specific role in maintaining life. Each organ system consists of a number of organs that operate collectively to carry out certain body functions. At every level of organization, whether at the cellular, tissue, organ, or organ system level, each structure always reflects its function and vice versa. This concept is known as the principle of complementarity of structure and function.

As you progress through this investigation of rabbit anatomy, consider how the form of each particular structure is appropriate for its function. For example, the rabbit’s sharp <button class='glossary-text'>incisors</button> enable it to cut the plants that it eats and to gnaw through roots when burrowing. Matching form with function is a part of any in-depth anatomical study. Before you begin the dissection, read the entire procedure carefully and familiarize yourself with commonly used terms. Important terms are boldfaced if they appear in a corresponding figure.

One of the greatest challenges in learning anatomy is mastering the extensive vocabulary. Dissection provides an opportunity to learn the names of and the relationships between the various structures. The terms in <button class='resource-text'>Table 1</button> and Figure 1 are consistently used in directing dissection procedures and describing the locations and orientations of anatomical structures. Refer often to Table 1 and Figure 1 as you work through the dissection activities. Note that, when facing a specimen, your right side correlates with the left side of the specimen and vice versa.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Body planes and directions in the rabbit
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Body planes and directions in the rabbit

tableData.text: Toward the right or left side
Near or toward the point of reference
Away from the point of reference
A significant distance below the surface
Divides the body into longitudinal left and right portions
Divides the body into equal left and right halves; often referred to as the midline or median plane
Perpendicular to the long axis; produces cross sections
Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

pageData.text: You will begin the investigation by examining the external structures of the rabbit. Then you will take a closer look at the muscular, digestive, respiratory, circulatory, and urogenital systems. (Information on the skeletal system is included in the appendix for reference. The nervous system is not examined in this investigation, because the brain and spinal cord are not accessible without specialized dissecting tools.)

pageData.question: What will you see when you lay your specimen on its ventral surface?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: If a specimen is placed ventrally (belly side down), the dorsal surface (back) can be observed.

pageData.question: What will you see when you lay your specimen on its dorsal surface?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: If a specimen is placed dorsally (back side down), the ventral surface (belly) can be observed.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: There are many ways a specimen can be positioned for examination. An imaginary plane can be visualized that divides the body into portions. The midsagittal plane divides the body into equal left and planes. If a specimen is placed on the belly, the dorsal surface, including the back of the head and feet, can be observed. If a specimen is placed dorsally, the ventral surface can be observed.

pageData.desc: This map describes the procedural workflow for Activities 1 through 4 of this investigation. Before starting any activities, set up your work area and dissection tools. In Activity 1, you will place the specimen on its ventral surface. Next, examine the external structures of the head, the structures of the oral cavity, and the structures of the trunk. Remove the skin from the specimen. Then, locate and identify the superficial musculature. .secure the specimen in the standard anatomical position. Next, open the ventral body cavity and examine the structures of the digestive system.   Open the thoracic cavityexamine the structures of the respiratory system.
pageData.altText: This map describes the procedural workflow for Activities 1 through 4 of this investigation. Before starting any activities, set up your work area and dissection tools. In Activity 1, you will place the specimen on its ventral surface. Next, examine the external structures of the head, the structures of the oral cavity, and the structures of the trunk. Remove the skin from the specimen. Then, locate and identify the superficial musculature. .secure the specimen in the standard anatomical position. Next, open the ventral body cavity and examine the structures of the digestive system. Open the thoracic cavityexamine the structures of the respiratory system.

pageData.desc: This map describes the procedural workflow for Activities 5 and 6 of this investigation. In Activity 5, you will examine the structures of the circulatory system. In Activity 6, you will examine the structures of the urinary system. Then, you will determine the sex of the specimen. If the specimen is male, examine the structures of the male reproductive system. If not, examine the structures of the female reproductive system.
pageData.altText: This map describes the procedural workflow for Activities 5 and 6 of this investigation. In Activity 5, you will examine the structures of the circulatory system. In Activity 6, you will examine the structures of the urinary system. Then, you will determine the sex of the specimen. If the specimen is male, examine the structures of the male reproductive system. If not, examine the structures of the female reproductive system.

pageData.subTitle: Personal protective equipment (PPE)
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Follow the instructions for this activity closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including using appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE); safety goggles, gloves, and a lab apron must be worn while dissecting. Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing the dissection. Do not eat the specimen. Review pertinent portions of any Safety Data Sheets (SDS) before beginning the activity. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) is flammable. Keep away from open flame if using alcohol as a disinfectant.
pageData.desc: flammable symbol
pageData.altText: flammable symbol

pageData.text: Dissections require special attention to safety. Please follow these additional precautions:

text: Clean the counter or work space thoroughly before and after the dissection. If isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant) is insufficient for removing grease during cleanup, you may use soap and water, followed by more alcohol/disinfectant.
Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before and after the dissection.
Only perform the dissection on the dissecting tray. This will contain both the specimen and any excess fluids.
Spread the absorbent pad blue-side down underneath the tray to capture any spilled fluid.
In general, scissors are used more frequently than the scalpel, especially when care must be taken not to cut too deeply into the specimen.

pageData.desc: Cutting a Specimen

text: Scalpels are used infrequently in most dissection labs and require special handling and disposal:

pageData.desc: Proper Scalpel Use

pageData.text:
• Never cut toward your holding hand and fingers.
  • Cut in a downward motion using a steady, even pressure.
  • Always use a sharp blade.
  • Do not use a scalpel that is nicked, bent, or damaged.
  • Do not use a scalpel to cut through bone or heavy cartilage.
  • Never use a scalpel for anything other than dissection.

pageData.subTitle: Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>
pageData.text: Independent, certified laboratory analyses of specimens fixed in Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> have found that it is nontoxic and does not give off dangerous fumes. This means that, for safety purposes, use of Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> specimens does not require specialized ventilation. Carolina does recommend performing the dissection in a well-ventilated room with some active ventilation when working with any preserved specimens. For a home setting, this may include opening windows and turning on a ceiling fan. The safe nature of Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> also means that in most localities there are no mandated disposal requirements.
Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> causes mild skin irritation if suitable PPE is not worn. Avoid contact with skin and <button class='glossary-text'>eyes</button>.
pageData.desc: warning symbol
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.subTitle: Storage of Specimens
pageData.text: If it is necessary to store the specimen between work periods, place it in the plastic storage bag with as much of the original solution as possible. Establishing an airtight seal is the best way to retain specimen integrity and prevent drying out of the specimen. First, squeeze as much air out of the specimen bag as possible before securing the opening with a rubber band, tape, or a binder clip. After closing the bag, the specimen can be stored in a larger, airtight box or bag at room temperature.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: An incision made along either the left or right side of a specimen would be referred to by which of the following terms?
When dissecting a quadruped, such as a rabbit, the specimen is often placed on the tray ventral-side up. Which of the following structures of the specimen is facing up in this position?
Which of the following best describes the anatomical direction “proximal”?

options.text: near or toward the point of reference
a significant distance below the surface

assestmentData.question: During a dissection, you may be asked to cut your specimen into equal left and right halves. Along which of the following planes would you make your incision?
Which of the following rabbit organ systems will NOT be examined in this investigation due to the need for special dissecting tools?
Which of the following scenarios describes inappropriate handling of a scalpel?

options.text: Yasmine places her holding hand inferior to the movement of her scalpel.
Julia disposes of her scalpel after noticing the blade is bent.
Ashley uses consistent pressure as she makes a small incision.
Rachel makes an incision by moving the scalpel down toward the tray.
Quincey trades the scalpel for scissors when she encounters thick cartilage mid-incision.

If you are or may become pregnant, do not open the specimen.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read over each activity before beginning work.
Print out the dissection procedure to avoid getting fluid from the specimen on your computer or mobile device.

Clean the work area. Put on your PPE—safety goggles, gloves, and lab apron—and keep them on during the dissection activity and cleanup. Change gloves when handling a computer, a phone, a camera, or other items during the dissection to prevent contamination. Place the camera or mobile device used for photography in a transparent bag to avoid contaminating it.
Lay the pad on the work area with the white, absorbent side facing up and blue side facing down.
Lay the scissors, scalpel, forceps, blunt probe, and any additional dissection tools on the pad.
Place the dissecting tray in the middle of the pad to absorb any fluid that might spill onto the work area.
Note: For each activity, take at least one photograph of each structure described. Your instructor may require you to turn in photos to document your work.
In Activity 1, you will examine the external structures of the preserved rabbit specimen while it is <button class='glossary-text'>ventral</button> side down.

typeBefore.text: Begin by examining the external anatomy of the rabbit. Notice the hair. The presence of hair, at least at some point in their development, is a distinguishing feature of mammals. Hair serves a vital role in thermoregulation in most species of mammals and also protects the skin. Observe the following external structures of the rabbit.

pageData.text: Lay your specimen on its <button class='glossary-text'>ventral</button> surface (as shown in Figure 2). Examine its exterior carefully. Note that the rabbit can be divided into three sections: the <button class='glossary-text'>head</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>trunk</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>tail</button>. The head is separated from the trunk by the neck.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: The three sections of the rabbit
pageData.altText: Figure 2: The three sections of the rabbit

pageData.text: Specialized hairs, <button class='glossary-text'>vibrissae</button>, or whiskers, are typically found on the face (see Figure 3). They are used as part of the rabbit’s sensory system and help the animal gather tactile information about its surroundings. Examine the head to view the vibrissae.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: The external anatomy of the rabbit’s head, labeled
pageData.altText: Figure 3: The external anatomy of the rabbit’s head, labeled

pageData.text:
While examining the head, note the other sensory structures (see Figure 3).
  1. The rabbit’s are large and set laterally on the head. positioning increases field of vision but reduces depth perception. Also, because of the placement of the eyes, a rabbit has a small blind spot directly in front of its face. This eye positioning is common in animals that have many predators.

Compared with humans, rabbits tend to be farsighted—their focus is worse on things that are nearby but better on things at a distance (such as approaching predators). Rabbits tend to be crepuscular (most active near twilight and dawn) and have good vision in low light conditions.

1. Protecting the eyes are upper and lower lids and a partial located in the corner of the eye. Because it is transparent, the nictitating membrane allows for some protection and moistening without as great of a loss of vision as blinking of the eyelids. Humans retain only a vestige of the nictitating membrane.
  2. The , or nostrils, are not only the openings to the respiratory system but are also crucial to the sensory system, allowing rabbits to gather olfactory information from their environment. The nares are enclosed by lateral folds, which radiate from the median cleft.
  3. The external part of the ear, the (plural, pinnae), directs sound waves into the auditory meatus, or ear canal. A rabbit can hear a greater range of frequencies than a human. The pinnae function also in thermoregulation; in fact, the surface area of the ears may occupy as much as 10 percent of the overall surface area of a rabbit.

Open the <button class='glossary-text'>mouth</button> of the rabbit and examine its dentition. If the jaws prove too stiff, use the closed tip of the scissors to gently pry them apart. It may be necessary to use the scissors or scapel to make <button class='glossary-text'>deep</button> incisions through each cheek at the corners of the mouth. Avoid cutting into the roof of the oral cavity. Rabbits are lagomorphs, belonging to an order of mammals that share certain characteristics with rodents. Like a rodent, a rabbit has <button class='glossary-text'>incisors</button> that are open-rooted and grow continuously throughout the animal’s life. Unlike a rodent, a rabbit has four incisors in its upper jaw. The smaller pair behind the front incisors are referred to as peg teeth. As you examine the dentition, consider the rabbit’s diet. The digestion of food begins in the mouth. Food is mechanically broken down by the teeth, while salivary enzymes begin the food’s chemical breakdown.

Observe the taste buds, the sensory organs located in the mouth, especially on the tongue. The rabbit has a good sense of taste, which helps it determine potential toxicity and nutritional value of plants that it nibbles.

After examining the rabbit’s head, examine its trunk. Note the paired feet and legs. The rabbit’s feet and legs are modified for hopping, also known as saltatorial locomotion. Mammals with saltatorial locomotion tend to have enlarged muscular hind limbs, to have reduced forelimbs, and to live in open spaces.
You will start Activity 2 by skinning the specimen. Then, you will examine its <button class='glossary-text'>superficial</button> musculature.

typeBefore.text: The muscular system consists of skeletal muscle, which contracts to move bones. A typical skeletal muscle is attached to two bones by tendons. The attachment point to the bone that is moved during contraction is called the muscle’s insertion. The muscle’s origin is the stationary point of attachment. To observe the musculature, you must first skin the rabbit as described in Steps 1–8 and illustrated by the incision lines on Figure 4. After removing the skin, refer to the muscle diagrams (see Figures 5 and 6) to identify the <button class='glossary-text'>superficial</button> muscles of the rabbit. Consider the function of each muscle as you examine it. Try to find the origin and insertion of some of the muscles that you examine.

typeBefore.desc: Figure 4: Incision lines for skinning the rabbit
typeBefore.altText: Figure 4: Incision lines for skinning the rabbit

pageData.text: Now you are ready to skin the rabbit. Lay the rabbit on its <button class='glossary-text'>ventral</button> surface.
Massage the skin in the <button class='glossary-text'>dorsal</button> neck area to loosen a portion of the skin from the underlying muscle.
With the scalpel, make a small incision in the center of the area of loosened skin.
Using the scissors, cut a shallow incision down the dorsal midline toward the <button class='glossary-text'>tail</button>. As you cut, pull the skin away from the underlying muscles.
From this cut, use the scissors to make additional cuts down the <button class='glossary-text'>lateral</button> surface of each leg and around the wrists and ankles.
Additionally, cut around the neck, tail, anus, and external genitalia. Ensure that you do not damage the genitalia while making the cuts.

After all cuts are made, separate the skin from the underlying muscles by using a blunt probe or closed sissors to tear through the superficial fascia while pulling the skin away from the <button class='glossary-text'>body</button>. As you separate the skin near the neck, you will see the platysma, fine parallel muscle fibers that are attached to the skin. Remove this muscle as you remove the skin. As you separate the skin from the muscles on the rabbit’s ventral surface, you will see that the skin is attached to a thin sheet of muscle, the <button class='glossary-text'>cutaneous maximus</button>, which originates at the linea alba (the white, fibrous structure that runs down the middle of the abdomen and corresponds to the ventral midline).

The cutaneous maximus may remain attached to the skin, so as you pull the skin away from the body, cut through this muscle’s attachment points to the along the midline and in the axillary (armpit) region of each of the four legs on the rabbit. Be careful not to damage any of the other muscles. Finally, remove the skin by pulling it down from the ventral cranial region toward the caudal region. Skin should remain only on the feet, , tail, and genitalia of the rabbit.
Proceed to identify specific muscles, guided by Figure 5 for superficial pectoral muscles and Figure 6 for superficial pelvic muscles (dorsal view on the left and ventral view on the right).

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Dorsal view on the left and ventral view on the right of the superficial pectoral muscles from the rabbit; muscles are labeled.
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Dorsal view on the left and ventral view on the right of the superficial pectoral muscles from the rabbit; muscles are labeled.

pageData.desc: Figure 6: Dorsal view on the left and ventral view on the right of the superficial pelvic muscles
pageData.altText: Figure 6: Dorsal view on the left and ventral view on the right of the superficial pelvic muscles

pageData.text: In Activity 3, you will examine the organs of the rabbit digestive system while it is <button class='glossary-text'>dorsal</button> side down.

typeBefore.text: In this activity, you will examine the digestive system of the rabbit (see Figure 14). These grazing animals feed mostly on grass and other herbaceous plants, and thus take in a great deal of fiber. Although the initial portions of the digestive tract (the <button class='glossary-text'>esophagus</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>stomach</button>, and small intestine) are very similar to those of humans, the later portions (particularly the <button class='glossary-text'>cecum</button>) are specialized to maximize the extraction and absorption of nutrients.

pageData.text:
To begin your examination of the digestive system, use rubber bands and/or twine to secure the skinned rabbit on its side in the dissecting tray.
  1. Cut through the muscular wall of the abdomen from the pubic arch to the bottom of the most rib. Be very careful not to cut too since this might damage the underlying organs.
  2. Cut two additional incisions from the linea alba, at the midline, around the rabbit to the dorsal side, almost to the vertebral column.
  3. Carefully fold the flaps of skin and muscle laterally. Do not disturb the underlying organs.
  4. Pin the flaps to the tray to expose the abdominal cavity. The exposed cavity is the abdominal cavity. to that cavity is the thoracic cavity. The two cavities are separated by a thin sheet of muscle called the (see Figure 7).

pageData.desc: Figure 7: Abdominal cavity, labeled
pageData.altText: Figure 7: Abdominal cavity, labeled

pageData.text: A prominent organ in the anterior of the abdominal cavity is the liver. This reddish-brown organ is divided into right and left lobes by the <button class='glossary-text'>falciform ligament</button>. Each of these lobes is further divided into median and <button class='glossary-text'>lateral</button> lobes, for a total of four lobes of the liver. The liver produces some amino acids, filters the blood, converts harmful substances into harmless ones, and helps to regulate blood sugar. Additionally, in the digestive system, the liver produces bile, which emulsifies fat during digestion.

Raise the right lobe of the liver and observe the <button class='glossary-text'>gallbladder</button>, which can sometimes be seen as a dark, greenish-yellow sac (see Figure 8). The bile produced by the liver is stored in the gallbladder.

pageData.desc: Figure 8: Abdominal cavity showing the gallbladder, labeled
pageData.altText: Figure 8: Abdominal cavity showing the gallbladder, labeled

pageData.text: As you continue to examine the abdominal cavity, trace the path of food through the digestive system. Each swallow of food forms a bolus that travels from the down the esophagus, which is not clearly visible in this view. The majority of the esophagus, located in the thoracic cavity, is best examined during observation of the circulatory system (see Figures 10 and ). Some small portion may be visible at the most anterior portion of the stomach. After leaving the esophagus, the food reaches the stomach, located on the left side of the rabbit, beneath the diaphragm.
Lift the liver to view the entire stomach (see Figure 9).

pageData.desc: Figure 9: Abdominal cavity showing the stomach. Labeled
pageData.altText: Figure 9: Abdominal cavity showing the stomach. Labeled

pageData.text:
The stomach consists of four portions: the , or cardia; the ; the ; and the , or the pylorus (see Figure 10).
  1. The cardiac region is the area where the stomach joins the esophagus. In this region, the separates the esophagus from the stomach. (Malfunction of this sphincter is a cause of acid reflux in humans.)
  2. The fundus is the upper curve of the stomach that lies to the left side of the esophagus. The body is the main portion of the stomach.
  3. The pyloric region lies to the right of the esophagus and terminates in the , which separates the stomach from the , the first portion of the small intestine (see Figure 12). In the stomach, chemical and mechanical digestion continue as muscular contractions mix the bolus with digestive secretions, forming a mixture called chyme.

pageData.desc: Figure 10: Diagram of the stomach, labeled
pageData.altText: Figure 10: Diagram of the stomach, labeled

pageData.text: Open the stomach and remove any food from the inner surface. Examine the internal surface of the stomach. Note the deep folds, or rugae, that allow the stomach to expand without pressure.

Though not part of the digestive system, the <button class='glossary-text'>spleen</button> is best viewed at this point (see Figure 11). The spleen is located on the greater curvature of the stomach, the larger convex curve. It is a small, dark, reddish-brown organ. The spleen is part of the lymphatic system and serves to filter blood.

pageData.desc: Figure 11: Abdominal cavity showing the stomach and spleen, which are labeled
pageData.altText: Figure 11: Abdominal cavity showing the stomach and spleen, which are labeled

pageData.desc: Figure 12: Abdominal cavity showing the pancreas, stomach, and duodenum
pageData.altText: Figure 12: Abdominal cavity showing the pancreas, stomach, and duodenum

pageData.text: From the stomach, the chyme travels through the pyloric sphincter into the duodenum. It is here that the common , formed from the bile duct of the liver and the of the gallbladder, and the pancreatic duct from the meet the small intestine to release additional enzymes to continue the process of digestion (see Figure 14).

From the duodenum, the mixture travels to the <button class='glossary-text'>jejunum</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>ileum</button>, the other sections of the small intestine, which are difficult to distinguish. The caudal end of the ileum is modified into a round muscular enlargement called the <button class='glossary-text'>sacculus rotundus</button> (see Figures 13 and 14). The sacculus rotundus is a structure found only in rabbits. It has a large amount of lymphoid tissue and is involved in the immune system.

pageData.desc: Figure 13: Abdominal cavity showing the intestinal tract with labels
pageData.altText: Figure 13: Abdominal cavity showing the intestinal tract with labels

pageData.desc: Figure 14: Diagram of the digestive system with labels. The left side shows the digestive system in the rabbit; the right side shows it extracted from the rabbit.
pageData.altText: Figure 14: Diagram of the digestive system with labels. The left side shows the digestive system in the rabbit; the right side shows it extracted from the rabbit.

pageData.text: Carefully cut longitudinally along a portion of the small intestine. The small intestine is lined with thousands of circular folds, the plicae circulares. There are also small projections called villi. Each villus has its own projections—the microscopic, hairlike microvilli. The folds and projections increase the surface area of the small intestine and maximize the absorption of nutrients. The small intestine ends at the ileocecal valve.

Within the mesentery of the small intestine is the pancreas, a pinkish-brown, somewhat granular mass (see Figure 12). The pancreas opens to the small intestine through the pancreatic duct at the caudal end of the duodenum. It is part of both the digestive and endocrine systems and secretes both enzymes and hormones.

Materials exit the small intestine through the sacculus rotundus to the large intestine first to a short compartment called the ampulla cecalis coli (a connection between the cecum and the ) and then to the colon (see Figure 13). In the first section of the colon, the , special contractions separate materials that are more digestible from those that are less digestible and force the nutritious components backward into the . The rougher materials continue along the .

The cecum is a large, coiled blind sac that extends from the sacculus rotundus. The cecum makes up a larger proportion of the digestive tract in rabbits than it does in any other group of animals, and it is critical to the digestion of rabbits’ food. Within the cecum, bacteria break down the material through fermentation.

At certain times, material from the cecum is released to the colon where it is coated in mucus and excreted through the anus in the form of soft balls called cecotropes, also known as night feces or soft feces. Rabbits immediately eat their cecotropes, and the materials pass again through the digestive system. The rabbit extracts additional nutrients from the food due to the fermentative changes that occurred in the cecum. Rabbits’ digestion exemplifies one type of hindgut fermentation. Cattle and other ruminants are called foregut fermenters because microbial fermentation of their food occurs before the food reaches the intestine.Although the rabbit colon can be divided into the ascending, transverse, and descending colon, it is usually discussed in terms of the proximal and distal colon. A short, muscular portion called the fusus coli marks the division between the two. This section helps regulate the complex events that move materials either forward or backward and that determine whether cecotropes or dry feces are being produced.

The beginning section of the proximal colon has a lumpy appearance because it includes many pouches called <button class='glossary-text'>haustra</button> between longitudinal bands called <button class='glossary-text'>taenia</button> (see Figure 13).
The distal colon is a long, twisted tube that terminates with the rectum.
In Activity 4, you will examine the organs of the rabbit respiratory system.

typeBefore.text: Notice that the thoracic cavity of the rabbit is relatively small in comparison to its abdominal cavity, from which it is separated by the <button class='glossary-text'>diaphragm</button>. The <button class='glossary-text'>trachea</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>bronchi</button>, and lungs are respiratory structures of the thoracic cavity. The respiratory system of the rabbit, like that of all animals, serves to acquire oxygen and expel carbon dioxide.

pageData.text:
To view the respiratory system, open the thoracic cavity.
  1. Cut along the midline, from the diaphragm to the base of the neck. As you make your incisions, you will be cutting through some musculature as well as the cartilage of the ribs.
  2. Fold back the musculature and ribs on both sides to expose the cavity. Pin the musculature down to expose the thoracic cavity.

You have already examined the nares, the external portion of the rabbit’s nose. Rabbits are obligate nasal breathers—a rabbit cannot breathe through its mouth due to the position of the glottis (opening to the respiratory system from the throat) and the epiglottis (cartilage flap positioned just above the glottis). The throat, also called the pharynx, is the area just <button class='glossary-text'>posterior</button> to the oral cavity and common to both the respiratory and digestive systems.

As you examine the features of the respiratory system, follow the path of an inhaled breath. From the nares, air travels to the pharynx, past the glottis and epiglottis, to the larynx (voice box), and then to the trachea (see Figure 15). To view the larynx and trachea, extend the midline incision toward the chin, making a shallow cut to avoid damaging the underlying structures. Then, using a blunt instrument, tease away any surrounding tissue.

pageData.desc: Figure 15: Thoracic cavity, without the heart, showing the trachea, bronchus, and lungs
pageData.altText: Figure 15: Thoracic cavity, without the heart, showing the trachea, bronchus, and lungs

pageData.text: The larynx, a cartilaginous structure, protects the entrance to the trachea and is important in vocalization. Posterior to the larynx is the trachea. The trachea is a long tube ringed with bands of cartilage that provide support and prevent collapse.

The trachea continues posteriorly until it divides into left and right bronchi (singular, bronchus) to the . These bronchi lead to the left and right lungs. In the lungs, the bronchi branch farther into smaller bronchioles, which terminate in containing alveoli, where most gas exchange occurs. (These structures will not be visible due to their size.)

Notice that the lungs of the rabbit are divided into three portions: the anterior, middle, and posterior lobes. Due to the position of the heart on the left side of the cavity, the left anterior lobe is much smaller than its counterpart on the right.
In Activity 5, you will examine the <button class='glossary-text'>heart</button> and blood vessels of the rabbit circulatory system.

typeBefore.text: The circulatory system transports various substances through the , including dissolved gases, nutrients, hormones, defensive cells, and cellular wastes. Like other mammals, rabbits possess a highly branched network of vessels and a four-chambered (see Figure 18). The heart and its associated vessels—along with the , , and several other important structures—lie in a central region of the thoracic cavity called the .There are two circulatory pathways: pulmonary and systemic. In pulmonary circulation, deoxygenated blood is pumped from the right side of the heart to the lungs and oxygenated blood flows back to the left side of the heart. In systemic circulation, this oxygenated blood is pumped from the left side of the heart throughout the body and deoxygenated blood travels back to the right side of the heart.

pageData.text: To fully view the heart, carefully remove the thymus gland, part of the the lymphatic, immune system, and endocrine systems.

The heart is covered by a membrane called the <button class='glossary-text'>pericardium</button>, or pericardial sac. Carefully lift it away from the heart and make an incision in it. In a living rabbit, the pericardial sac is full of fluid, which protects and cushions the heart.

Once you have removed the pericardial sac, examine the four chambers of the heart (see Figures 16 and 17). Two dark, thinner-walled <button class='glossary-text'>atria</button> are <button class='glossary-text'>anterior</button> to the two thicker-walled <button class='glossary-text'>ventricles</button>. The organization of the heart keeps oxygenated and deoxygenated blood separated.

pageData.desc: Figure 16: External ventral view of the heart, labeled
pageData.altText: Figure 16: External ventral view of the heart, labeled

pageData.desc: Figure 17: External dorsal view of the heart with the anterior and posterior vena cava labeled
pageData.altText: Figure 17: External dorsal view of the heart with the anterior and posterior vena cava labeled

pageData.text:
To trace the flow of blood through the heart, slice a opening by making a smooth, continuous partial incision into the heart’s left side.
  1. Carefully fold the ventral portion away from the portion, as if opening a book. Deoxygenated blood from the body enters the via the , the , and the .
  2. From the right atrium, blood flows through the tricuspid valve into the .
  3. The blood is then pumped through the to the lungs by way of the . are vessels that carry blood away from the heart. Valves prevent the blood from flowing back into the chamber from which it came.
  4. In the lungs, the blood becomes oxygenated through gas exchange in the alveoli.
  5. The blood then returns to the heart through the . are vessels that carry blood toward the heart. The blood enters the heart again in the and travels through the bicuspid valve to the .
  6. From the left ventricle, the blood is pumped through the aortic valve and out of the heart through the , the largest in the body.

Following the path of the aorta, you will see that it immediately makes a posterior turn, forming the (see Figure 18).
  1. Continuing caudally from the arch, the dorsal aorta supplies blood to the posterior portion of the body (and may be called the abdominal aorta below the ).
  2. The first branch from the dorsal aorta is the celiac artery (or celiac ).
  3. The celiac artery diverges to form the hepatic artery, which supplies the liver, and the gastrosplenic artery, which further subdivides to serve the and .
  4. Continuing caudally, locate the superior mesenteric artery, which supplies blood to the small intestine.
  5. Find the paired that carry blood to the . (You might want to find the kidneys first, described in Activity 6, and work backward from there.)
  6. Locate the gonadal arteries, which deliver blood to the in males, in which they are known as the , or the in females, in which they are known as the (see and ).
  7. Farther along the dorsal aorta, you will see the paired iliolumbar arteries that carry blood to the muscles of the back.
  8. The last major branch from the dorsal aorta forms the right common and the left common iliac arteries, which supply blood to the legs.

pageData.desc: Figure 18: Diagram of the thoracic cavity with the heart. The top left is the superficial view of the thoracic cavity with the deep view of this cavity directly below. The top right is the ventral view of the heart with the dorsal view below. All images contain labels.
pageData.altText: Figure 18: Diagram of the thoracic cavity with the heart. The top left is the superficial view of the thoracic cavity with the deep view of this cavity directly below. The top right is the ventral view of the heart with the dorsal view below. All images contain labels.

pageData.text:
Blood travels through the aortic arch and to the anterior regions of the body through several important vessels (see Figure 18).
  1. The coronary arteries supply blood to the heart muscle itself.
  2. The right supplies blood to the right (which leads into the right shoulder) and the right common (which leads to the ). Likewise, the left brachiocephalic artery supplies blood to the left subclavian artery and the left common carotid artery.

Veins have less-muscular walls than arteries and tend to be more (i.e., major arteries tend to lie deeper in the body than the major veins). The veins merge until they reach the venae cavae, which return blood to the right atrium of the heart. The venous system is in some ways the inverse of the branching arterial system.
  1. As you trace the posterior vena cava cranially, you can locate the paired iliolumbar veins, the paired gonadal veins, and the paired .
  2. The hepatic portal vein drains the liver and merges with the posterior vena cava near the diaphragm before flowing into the right atrium.
  3. Blood drains from the head via the transverse jugular vein and the external jugular veins, and from there into the subclavian veins, which merge to form the anterior vena cava.
You will start Activity 6 by examining the rabbit urinary system. You will then identify the sex of your specimen to determine which reproductive structures to locate and identify.

typeBefore.text: The urogenital system consists of the urinary and the reproductive systems, which share some components. The urinary system removes nitrogenous wastes from the <button class='glossary-text'>body</button> as urine, and it also regulates osmotic pressure. The reproductive system produces the gametes (the male’s sperm and female’s ova) necessary for the formation of offspring. It also includes the structures involved in the sexual transfer of sperm to ova and in the protection, development, and birth of young.

pageData.text: To view the urinary system (see Figures 19 and 20), remove the rabbit’s liver by carefully lifting it out of the rabbit and cutting through the tissue that secures it in place. Push the visceral organs to the right side of the specimen. The <button class='glossary-text'>kidneys</button>, two bean-shaped organs, are partially embedded on the <button class='glossary-text'>dorsal</button> surface of the abdominal cavity. The kidneys filter waste from the bloodstream, regulate the amount of water in the rabbit, and maintain appropriate concentrations of certain ions.

pageData.desc: Figure 19: Diagram of the kidneys and associated structures, labeled
pageData.altText: Figure 19: Diagram of the kidneys and associated structures, labeled

pageData.desc: Figure 20: The upper portion of the urinary system showing the locations of the kidney, ureter, and urinary bladder
pageData.altText: Figure 20: The upper portion of the urinary system showing the locations of the kidney, ureter, and urinary bladder

pageData.text: For the following steps, refer to Figures 19 and 20. Using a sharp scalpel, cut one of the kidneys in half longitudinally, along its flattened plane. As you examine the interior of the kidney, note the outer portion—the <button class='glossary-text'>renal cortex</button>—and the inner portion—the <button class='glossary-text'>renal medulla</button>.
As you examine the kidneys, observe the renal artery and renal vein, which carry blood into and out of the kidney.

Also notice the <button class='glossary-text'>adrenal glands</button>, one of which is <button class='glossary-text'>medial</button> to each kidney. The adrenal glands are part of the endocrine system.

The kidneys filter waste from the bloodstream and produce urine. The urine moves from the kidneys through the ureter to the <button class='glossary-text'>urinary bladder</button>, where it accumulates.

As the bladder fills, it is stimulated to contract, expelling the urine out through the <button class='glossary-text'>urethra</button>. In the female rabbit, the urethra empties into the <button class='glossary-text'>vestibule</button> (see Figure 22); in the male it continues to the <button class='glossary-text'>penis</button>, joining the reproductive system (see Figure 21).

pageData.desc: Figure 21: Male urogenital system, labeled
pageData.altText: Figure 21: Male urogenital system, labeled

pageData.desc: Figure 22: Female urogenital system, labeled
pageData.altText: Figure 22: Female urogenital system, labeled

pageData.text: In males (see Figure 21), the hormone testosterone and the sperm (the male gametes) are produced in the <button class='glossary-text'>testes</button>, two organs situated in the <button class='glossary-text'>scrotal sac</button> (scrotum). To view the testes, cut open the scrotum, located caudal to the penis. The testes are white, marbled, ovoid structures.

With a sharp scalpel, cut one of the testes in half. Examine the interior of the testis, noting the coiled tubules, <button class='glossary-text'>seminiferous tubules</button>, where sperm are produced.

Examine the <button class='glossary-text'>anterior</button> portion of the uncut testis and locate the <button class='glossary-text'>epididymis</button>, a tightly coiled tube that collects and stores sperm cells.
During ejaculation, the sperm are released from the epididymis to the <button class='glossary-text'>vas deferens</button> (ductus deferens), which transfers sperm from a testis to the urethra.

The <button class='glossary-text'>seminal vesicle</button>, which secretes a fluid into the ductus deferens, lies at the base of the bladder. This fluid combines with the sperm and with fluid from the prostate to produce semen. The prostate is seen as a thickening of the dorsal wall of the seminal vesicle.

The semen passes through the urethra and out through the tip of the <button class='glossary-text'>penis</button>. The free end of the penis, the glans penis, typically lies within a pouch of skin called the prepuce.
A small bone called the baculum, which stabilizes the penis during copulation, is inside the glans penis.

For the female reproductive system (see Figure 22), trace the path of the gametes produced by the female rabbit. In female specimens, the ova, female gametes, are produced by the <button class='glossary-text'>ovaries</button>. The ovaries can be found in the dorsal wall of the abdomen caudal to the kidneys. If the ovaries in your specimen are obscured by a layer of fat, carefully remove it to view them.

Once the ova mature, they are released from the ovaries into the <button class='glossary-text'>fallopian tubes</button>. Unlike humans, rabbits release multiple eggs at one time. Fertilization of these eggs typically produces a litter of 4 to 12 kits.

The fallopian tubes transport the eggs from the ovaries to the <button class='glossary-text'>uteri</button>. Rabbits have paired uteri, a distinct left uterus and right uterus, each with a muscular wall that distinguishes them from the fallopian tubes.
Each uterus enters the anterior of the <button class='glossary-text'>vagina</button> through a separate cervix terminating at the <button class='glossary-text'>external uterine aperture</button>.
The vagina and the urethra (from the urinary system), converge at the vestibule, or urogenital sinus, which opens to the exterior at the , or urogenital orifice.

text: Dispose of any leftover Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> fluid down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run for about half a minute to dilute the solution.
Rinse and carefully air-dry the dissection tools, and return the materials to your equipment kit.
If you are finished working with your specimen, place it in its storage bag, secure the opening, and put the bag in an opaque trash bag for disposal in the household garbage.
Sanitize the work space with 70% alcohol or other non-bleach disinfectant.

pageData.text: The Skeletal System
The skeletal system of the rabbit comprises both cartilage and bone. The system serves to support the <button class='glossary-text'>body</button> mass and to protect internal organs.

The skeletal system consists of two main parts: the axial skeleton and the appendicular skeleton. The axial skeleton is made up of the skull, vertebral column, ribs, and sternum. The appendicular skeleton includes the pectoral and pelvic girdles and their appendages. The pectoral appendages are the forelimbs, and the pelvic appendages are the hind limbs.

During the dissection of your rabbit, you may wish to refer to the skeleton diagram to identify the bones you encounter. The number in parenthesis in Figure 23 refer to the number of bones in that group of bones.

pageData.desc: Figure 23: Rabbit skeletal system, labeled
pageData.altText: Figure 23: Rabbit skeletal system, labeled

pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.title: Table 1.
pageData.content: Table 1. Common anatomical terms

tableData.text: Toward the right or left side
Near or toward the point of reference
Away from the point of reference
A significant distance below the surface
Divides the body into longitudinal left and right portions
Divides the body into equal left and right halves; often referred to as the midline or median plane
Perpendicular to the long axis; produces cross sections
Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

pageData.content: Experimental Design Diagram 1
pageData.altText: This map describes the procedural workflow for Activities 1 through 4 of this investigation. Before starting any activities, set up your work area and dissection tools. In Activity 1, you will place the specimen on its ventral surface. Next, examine the external structures of the head, the structures of the oral cavity, and the structures of the trunk. Remove the skin from the specimen. Then, locate and identify the superficial musculature. .secure the specimen in the standard anatomical position. Next, open the ventral body cavity and examine the structures of the digestive system. Open the thoracic cavityexamine the structures of the respiratory system.

pageData.content: Experimental Design Diagram 2
pageData.altText: This map describes the procedural workflow for Activities 5 and 6 of this investigation. In Activity 5, you will examine the structures of the circulatory system. In Activity 6, you will examine the structures of the urinary system. Then, you will determine the sex of the specimen. If the specimen is male, examine the structures of the male reproductive system. If not, examine the structures of the female reproductive system.

data.title: Adrenal gland
data.content: A small gland that makes steroid hormones

data.title: Anterior
data.content: Toward the front of the body; synonymous with cranial; synonymous with ventral in describing the biped body other than the head

data.title: Aorta
data.content: The largest artery, which receives the systemic output of the heart

data.title: Aortic arch
data.content: One of the arterial branches

data.title: Artery
data.content: A blood vessel that conveys blood away from the heart

data.title: Atria
data.content: The two upper chambers of the heart that receive blood as it enters the heart; also called receiving chambers

data.title: Bile duct
data.content: A tube that carries bile from the liver  and the gallbladder through the pancreas to the small intestine

data.title: Body
data.content: The largest part of an organ

data.title: Brachiocephalic artery
data.content: The blood vessel that supplies blood to the lungs

data.title: Bronchi
data.content: The two large airways that branch from the trachea; singular, bronchus

data.title: Cardiac region
data.content: The opening of the esophagus into the stomach; also called cardia

data.title: Cardiac sphincter
data.content: Separates the esophagus from the stomach

data.title: Carotid artery
data.content: The artery that carries blood from the heart to the head

data.title: Cecum
data.content: The pouch that forms the first part of the large intestine

data.title: Colon
data.content: The longest part of the large intestine

data.title: Cutaneous maximus
data.content: A thin sheet of muscle to which the skin is attached

data.title: Cystic duct
data.content: A tube that carries bile from the gall bladder

data.title: Deep
data.content: Below the surface of the body or a structure; internal

data.title: Diaphragm
data.content: A dome-shaped sheet of muscle that separates the chest cavity and abdominal cavities

data.title: Distal
data.content: Farther from the body’s midline or center; away from the point of reference

data.title: Distal colon
data.content: The last part of the large intestine

data.title: Dorsal
data.content: Toward the back of the body; synonymous with superior in quadrupeds, and in bipeds when referring to the head; synonymous with posterior in describing the biped body other than the head

data.title: Duodenum
data.content: The first portion of the small intestine

data.title: Epididymis
data.content: A tightly coiled tube that collects and stores sperm cells

data.title: Esophagus
data.content: A muscular tube that connects the throat to the stomach

data.title: External uterine aperture
data.content: The circular aperture on the extremity of the cervix

data.title: Eye
data.content: An organ for sight

data.title: Falciform ligament
data.content: A thin fibrous structure that connects the anterior part of the liver to the ventral wall of the abdomen

data.title: Fallopian tubes
data.content: Tubes that transport eggs from the ovaries to the uterus, or uteri in the case of rabbits

data.title: Frontal plane
data.content: Plane that divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

data.title: Fundus
data.content: The part of an organ that is farthest away from the organ's opening

data.title: Gallbladder
data.content: An organ that can sometimes be seen as a dark, greenish-yellow sac; it stores the bile produced by the liver

data.title: Haustra
data.content: Segmented pouches of the colon that give the proximal colon a lumpy appearance

data.title: Head
data.content: The uppermost or forwardmost part of body of a vertebrate; it contains the skull, nose, eyes, and mouth

data.title: Heart
data.content: A hollow muscular organ that pumps blood throughout the body

data.title: Ileum
data.content: The last portion of the small intestine

data.title: Incisors
data.content: Teeth located at the front of the mouth; they are designed for shearing or cutting

data.title: Jejunum
data.content: The middle part of the small intestine

data.title: Kidneys
data.content: Two bean-shaped organs that are responsible for the three processes involved in urine production

data.title: Lateral
data.content: Away from the midline of the body; to the side

data.title: Left anterior vena cava
data.content: One of two large veins that return deoxygenated blood to the heart from the head and neck, upper limbs, and thorax

data.title: Left atrium
data.content: One of four chambers of the heart; it receives blood from the lungs and delivers blood to the left ventricle

data.title: Left ventricle
data.content: One of the four chambers of the heart; it receives blood from the left atrium and delivers blood to the body

data.title: Medial
data.content: Toward the midline

data.title: Mediastinum
data.content: A central region of the thoracic cavity

data.title: Midsagittal plane
data.content: The plane that divides the body into equal left and right halves; often referred to as the midline or median plane

data.title: Mouth
data.content: It is the orifice through which food and air enter the body; also called the oral cavity

data.title: Nares
data.content: Openings to the respiratory system; also called nostrils

data.title: Nictitating membrane
data.content: A transparent structure located in the medial corner of the eye that allows for some protection and moistening without as great of a loss of vision as blinking the eyelids

data.title: Ovarian arteries
data.content: Spermatic arteries in females

data.title: Ovaries
data.content: The organs that produce female gametes (ova); they are located in the dorsal wall of the abdomen caudal to the kidneys; singular, ovary

data.title: Pancreas
data.content: The fish-shaped organ located in the abdominal cavity

data.title: Penis
data.content: The male genital organ; urine and sperm both leave the body through an opening in this structure

data.title: Pericardium
data.content: A membrane that surrounds the heart; also called the percardial sac

data.title: Pinna
data.content: The external part of the ear; it directs sound waves into the auditory meatus (ear canal); plural, pinnae

data.title: Posterior
data.content: Toward the back of the body; synonymous with caudal; synonymous with dorsal in describing the biped body other than the head

data.title: Posterior vena cava
data.content: The large vein that returns deoxygenated blood to the heart from the tail or rear; also called the postcava

data.title: Proximal
data.content: Near or toward the point of reference

data.title: Proximal colon
data.content: The first and middle parts of the colon

data.title: Pulmonary artery
data.content: The artery that carries blood from the right side of the heart to the lungs

data.title: Pulmonary valve
data.content: A valve between the pulmonary artery and the right ventricle of the heart that prevents blood from flowing back into the right ventricle

data.title: Pulmonary vein
data.content: The vein that carries blood to the left side of the heart from the lungs

data.title: Pyloric region
data.content: Connects the stomach to the small intestine

data.title: Pyloric sphincter
data.content: Separates the stomach from the duodenum

data.title: Renal arteries
data.content: Blood vessels that supply blood to the kidneys

data.title: Renal cortex
data.content: The outer portion of the kidney

data.title: Renal medulla
data.content: The inner portion of the kidney

data.title: Renal veins
data.content: Blood vessels that carry blood away from the kidneys

data.title: Right anterior vena cava
data.content: One of two large veins that return deoxygenated blood to the heart from the head and neck, upper limbs, and thorax

data.title: Right atrium
data.content: One of the four chambers of the heart; it receives blood from the body and delivers blood to the right ventricle

data.title: Right ventricle
data.content: One of the four chambers of the heart; it receives blood from the right atrium and delivers blood to the lungs

data.title: Sacculus rotundus
data.content: A structure found only in rabbits; a round muscular enlargement in the last portion of the small intestine that is involved in the immune system

data.title: Sagittal plane
data.content: Plane that divides the body into longitudinal left and right portions

data.title: Scrotal sac
data.content: The structure that surrounds the testes; also called the scrotum

data.title: Seminal vesicle
data.content: Secretes a fluid into the ductus deferens; it lies at the base of the bladder

data.title: Seminiferous tubules
data.content: Tubules inside the testes where sperm is produced

data.title: Spermatic arteries
data.content: A pair of arteries that supply blood to the testes or ovaries

data.title: Spleen
data.content: A ductless organ that is located in the left abdominal region near the stomach; it is involved in the production and removal of blood cells

data.title: Stomach
data.content: A muscular organ located on the left side of the upper abdomen; it receives food from the esophagus

data.title: Subclavian artery
data.content: The blood vessel that carries the main supply of blood to the arms

data.title: Superficial
data.content: Toward or along the surface of the body or a structure; external

data.title: Taenia
data.content: The longitudinal bands bordering the haustra of the proximal colon

data.title: Tail
data.content: A slender appendage at the rear many animals

data.title: Testes
data.content: The male gonads that produce sperm (the male gametes) and the hormone testosterone

data.title: Thymus
data.content: Located inferior to the thyroid gland and anterior to the heart; it belongs to the lymphatic, immune, and endocrine systems

data.title: Trachea
data.content: A tube with C-shaped rings of cartilage that extends from the larynx to the bronchial tubes; commonly referred to as the windpipe

data.title: Transverse plane
data.content: The plane perpendicular to the long axis; produces cross sections

data.title: Trunk
data.content: The part of the body to which the head and limbs are attached; also called the torso

data.title: Urethra
data.content: A duct via which urine leaves the body, and in males, sperm as well

data.title: Urinary bladder
data.content: The organ responsible for the temporary storage of urine

data.title: Uteri
data.content: The female reproductive organs that receive eggs from the ovaries; rabbits have paired uteri, a left uterus and a right uterus

data.title: Vagina
data.content: The muscular tube leading from the external female genitals to the cervix

data.title: Vas deferens
data.content: The duct that transfers sperm from a testis to the urethra; also called the ductus deferens

data.title: Veins
data.content: Blood vessels that convey blood toward the heart

data.title: Ventral
data.content: Toward the belly or abdomen of the body; synonymous with inferior in quadrupeds, and in bipeds when referring to the head

data.title: Ventricles
data.content: The two lower chambers of the heart that forcefully eject blood from the heart; also called the pumping chambers

data.title: Vestibular opening
data.content: The opening of the vestibule to the exterior; also called the urogenital orifice

data.title: Vestibule
data.content: The structure at which the vagina and urethra converge

data.title: Vibrissae
data.content: Specialized hairs typically found on the face; also called whiskers
